answers.text: the period spanning the reign of King Edward VII up to the end of the First World War,

qas.question: What event split the United Kingdom into two groups?
In what year did the Liberals win huge in the general election?
What led to a reduction in the power of the peers?

answers.text: Conflict between the two Houses of Parliament over the People's Budget

qas.question: Who held the balance of power in the 1910 election?

context: The Edwardian era in the United Kingdom is <a0_0>the period spanning the reign of King Edward VII up to the end of the First World War,<a0_0/> including the years surrounding the sinking of the RMS Titanic. In the early years of the period, the <a1_0>Second Boer War<a1_0/> in South Africa split the country into anti- and pro-war factions. The imperial policies of the Conservatives eventually proved unpopular and in the general election of <a2_0>1906<a2_0/> the Liberals won a huge landslide. The Liberal government was unable to proceed with all of its radical programme without the support of the House of Lords, which was largely Conservative. <a3_0>Conflict between the two Houses of Parliament over the People's Budget<a3_0/> led to a reduction in the power of the peers in 1910. The general election in January that year returned a hung parliament with the balance of power held by <a4_0>Labour and Irish Nationalist members.
